title: Before 1 October 2017, will the Mauritanian government hold a referendum to alter the nation's constitution?
possible_answers: Yes, but it will not pass
preds: I think I read something about this today.

Using the levers of power to silence the critics. This will probably happen, one way or another. http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/mauritania-referendum-campaign-starts-under-opposition-boycott-20170721
Hard to imagine holding a referendum without good confidence it will pass.

I think the referendum happens given its importance to the ruling party. I also think it passes because the opposition has called for a boycott of the vote (see link). Can someone please explain to me why anyone thinks boycotting events like this helps? Or point to a single example where boycotting didn't just lead to the government saying we won the vote end of story? https://www.africanindy.com/news/mauritania-opposition-vows-to-boycott-presidents-referendum-10237043
The wording "...passage of any of them [amendments] would resolve the question as "Yes, it will pass."

The risk exposure for allowing the rescheduled constitutional referendum in Mauritania seems unacceptable for the ruling party.  Even a predetermined referendum presents a significant risk of instability.  The issues up for a vote are extreme constitutional changes, such as reconfiguration of Senate elections, a new flag and a new national anthem.  The referendum is offering too many changes at one time.  Slavery is still legal, so manipulating or canceling elections should be tolerable to the leadership.
This doesn't seem to be very popular. If the referendum goes forward, I would anticipate it not being deemed "free and fair."

As everyone should have learned by now, referenda are a Really Bad Idea unless you can control the outcome; not clear this gummint can manage that.  Also, there are both legal and logistic difficulties to be overcome.  They may go ahead and run it anyway, and if so it will probably pass one way or another.  Stay tuned.

Several thousand Mauritanians took to the streets on Saturday to protest a controversial constitutional referendum due on August 5, according to AFP journalists at the demonstration organized by an opposition coalition.
https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/north-africa/2017/07/16/Thousands-take-to-streets-to-protest-Mauritania-referendum.html
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Already postponed once, reportedly due to incomplete preparations.  Also possible the delay is due to opposition from presidents own party.  Why hold a referendum before there is convincing evidence of the outcome?

https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Mauritania_2012.pdf
Yet another African president wants a constitutional change to be President-for-Life;  this may not pass without widespread intimidation and fraud, the possibility of which should not be discounted too severely.    Abolishing the Senate may be more popular, although the proposal is likely prompted by the fact that the would-be Prez-for-Life and the Senate don't play nicely together at the moment.  The proposed new flag is quite nice and there is no compelling reason not to adopt it, but the flag design is not in the Constitution, so approving a change wouldn't be a constitutional amendment anyway.  The more interesting issue is posed by Title XI,  Article 99, of the current Constitution: "Each  Bill  of  revision  must  be  voted  by  a  majority  of  two-thirds  (2/3)  of  the  Deputies
composing  the  National  Assembly  and  two-thirds  (2/3)  of  the  Senators  composing
the Senate, to be able to be submitted to referendum . "No  procedure  of  revision  of  the  Constitution  can  be  engaged  if  it  jeopardizes. . .  
the principle of democratic alternation in power and its corollary, the principle according
to which the mandate of the President of the Republic is of five years, renewable one sole time, as specified in Articles 26 and 28 above." So either the proposed referendum can't be binding or it can' t be legal, since the Senate didn't buy into it and it changes things the Constitution says can't be changed.   One supposes the referendum will go forward anyway, and the President will say some things about it that aren't true.   (Apparently presidents of some countries aren't strictly wedded to the truth; luckily for us, this is not the case in the US.)  Anyway, this should be interesting.  My current numbers are arbitrary but not random; subject to change without notice; not available in stores; member, FDIC.

I need to dig into this further, but it looks like this is not the most popular agenda item of the President. Apparently he attempted to abolish the Senate, of which the majority of members are from his party, and was surprised when they voted against such move (http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-4683028/Mauritania-opposition-vows-boycott-presidents-referendum.html).  Starting off on the more cautious side as I research further.
